findings.title: Container image contains XXE vulnerability (CVE-2023-38325) in HL7 parser
findings.description: The ehr-integration-service uses xml2js 0.4.23 for parsing HL7 messages from external EHR systems. XXE vulnerability allows reading arbitrary files including patient database credentials.
findings.remediation: Rebuild container image with xml2js 0.5.0 or later and redeploy immediately

findings.title: Container image contains RCE vulnerability (CVE-2024-23456) in DICOM image processor
findings.description: The imaging-storage service uses Sharp 0.31.3 for processing DICOM medical images. Buffer overflow allows remote code execution via malicious images.
findings.remediation: Upgrade Sharp to 0.32.0 or later immediately

findings.title: FHIR client token leakage vulnerability (CVE-2024-55555)
findings.description: The ehr-integration-service uses fhir-kit-client 1.9.2 which leaks authentication tokens. Allows unauthorized access to Epic and Cerner EHR systems.
findings.remediation: Upgrade fhir-kit-client to 2.0.0 or later immediately

findings.title: Patient database credentials stored without encryption at rest
findings.description: Kubernetes Secrets containing patient database credentials are not encrypted at rest. etcd encryption is not enabled in the cluster.
findings.remediation: Enable etcd encryption at rest, rotate all database credentials

findings.title: Patient database exposed to internet via security group misconfiguration
findings.description: Security group 'patients-db-sg' allows inbound traffic from 0.0.0.0/0 on port 5432. This exposes the PostgreSQL database containing all patient PHI to the internet.
findings.remediation: Restrict inbound rules to VPC CIDR blocks only

findings.title: S3 bucket containing DICOM medical images is publicly accessible
findings.description: The imaging-storage S3 bucket has public read access enabled. Contains 4.7TB of DICOM medical images (X-rays, MRIs, CT scans) with embedded patient identifiers.
findings.remediation: Remove public access, enable bucket encryption, implement access logging

findings.title: Telehealth service has overly permissive S3 access to all buckets
findings.description: The telehealth-service-role has s3:* permissions on all buckets. This violates least privilege and could allow unauthorized access to patient imaging and PHI backups.
findings.remediation: Restrict S3 permissions to specific buckets and actions (s3:GetObject, s3:PutObject) on telehealth-recordings-bucket only

findings.title: Prescription service logging controlled substance prescriptions in plaintext
findings.description: The prescription-service logs DEA-controlled substance prescriptions (opioids, benzodiazepines) in plaintext. Violates HIPAA Privacy Rule and DEA regulations.
findings.remediation: Implement log redaction for prescription details, encrypt logs at rest

findings.title: Unusual bulk PHI export detected - possible data exfiltration
findings.description: The ehr-integration-service pod exported 450,000 patient records in 15 minutes to an external IP address (203.0.113.42) not in the approved partner whitelist.
findings.remediation: Investigate immediately, review pod logs, implement egress network policies

findings.title: Patient portal container running with privileged mode
findings.description: The patient-portal container is running with privileged: true. This grants unnecessary host access and increases attack surface for internet-facing PHI application.
findings.remediation: Remove privileged mode, use securityContext with specific capabilities only
